title: What it’s like to be in Ellen’s studio audience
text:
Share on Twitter 
IF YOU ever get the chance to sit in Ellen’s studio audience, I have one piece of advice for you: pack your dancing shoes. 
I guarantee that you’ll spend more time on your feet shaking your booty during the taping than you have at any boozy wedding in the past. 
Here’s what my experience was like when I sat in the studio audience recently to watch an episode of the hugely successful talk show being filmed: 
Armed with a VIP pass (I know a guy) I arrived at a carpark across the road from Warner Bros. studio in Los Angeles at 1.30 in the afternoon. 
There were already hundreds of ticket holders gathered at the designated meeting place and the sense of excitement among the mostly female crowd was infectious. The exterior of Ellen’s studio. Source: Supplied The golden ticket. Source: Supplied 
Their spirits couldn’t be dampened, not even when one of Ellen’s staffers walked me to the front of the queue where they’d been lining up for hours and explained to them that I was a VIP. 
I did get one filthy look; but who knows, that could have been a case of resting bitch face. 
As a group we were then escorted across the road and into the studio that Ellen’s show is filmed in. 
After passing through the metal detectors at the security station, we were all taken into Ellen’s gift shop which sells everything from drink bottles to shoes and of course, Ellen branded undies. 
Pop music was blasting through the speakers in the gift shop area and even though we weren’t even on the set yet, the dancing had already begun. 
The female audience members started shaking their hips as they introduced themselves to complete strangers and snapped selfies with large Ellen posters on the wall. So many undies. Source: Supplied Inside the gift shop waiting area. Source: Supplied 
To quote Dennis Denuto from The Castle , “it’s just the vibe of the thing,” and the vibe inside the holding area was electric. 
After an hour of waiting and watching some truly memorable ‘mum dancing’, we were finally walked up some stairs and into the studio audience seats on Ellen’s set. 
The first thing I noticed was how small it is in real life compared to how big it looks on TV. 
The second thing I noticed was just how bloody cold it was. 
They probably crank the aircon to counteract the heat generated from the huge number of lights that hang from the studio ceiling. But then again, they could just be trying to cool us down as we danced non-stop, waiting for the comedian herself to appear. A cheeky photo of us entering Ellen’s studio. Source: Supplied 
Before long an audience warm-up guy walked on stage to pump up the crowd but seriously, his job could not have been more redundant. 
We were already frothing. 
The warm-up guy walked us through some basic instructions: You aren’t allowed to take photos but you are allowed (and encouraged) to laugh and clap as loudly as humanly possible. 
He also asked us if we knew what Ellen liked to do after opening the show and in unison the women around me screamed back, “DANCE!” 
And with that the crowd were off again, twisting and twostepping in the aisles as music was played over the speakers. 
The show’s resident DJ, tWitch, was then introduced and you’ll never guess what he did. Yep, he danced. 
Putting on a little show, he showed off an impressive array of moves as he walked through the studio audience challenging people to dance-offs. 
And then, about 25 minutes after we had entered the studio and had almost exhausted our repertoire of dance moves, the show was ready to start. 
The warm-up guy started a count down and the theme music to Ellen’s show kicked in. 
If I thought the audience was amped before, it was nothing to how compared to how they lost their s**t when the superstar herself walked out. 
Even if Jesus himself walked out had onto the stage during a Hillsong gathering, I don’t think the energy in the room would have topped this. 
After a long, long standing ovation, we took to our seats to listen to Ellen’s opening monologue. 
And then, just as she does at the start of every show, the comedian told tWitch to fire off a song and she danced her way into the studio audience. 
The show was under way and in the following segments Ellen interviewed 2 Broke Girls star, Beth Behrs, a gay couple from Iraq and there was a performance by the host’s favourite band, The Growlers. I was thinking about these two all weekend. #BeKindToOneAnother pic.twitter.com/nDWmQwTye6 — Ellen DeGeneres (@TheEllenShow) January 30, 2017 
The show was filmed as if it was live, with just a few minutes left in between segments for the commercial breaks. 
During the short breaks, Ellen would stay on the set and chat with her producers and practice her opening lines for the upcoming segment. 
And what did we, the studio audience, do in those breaks? 
More bloody dancing. 
At one stage, the warm-up guy told each row to come up with a dance move and perform it together but unfortunately my row lacked a dominant personality and we spent the entire time staring at each other awkwardly waiting for someone to pick a move. 
After just 50 minutes, the taping was over. Ellen said farewell to the cameras but then stayed on set to have a super quick chat to the studio audience. 
She thanked us for our energy and encouraged us to spread joy out in the world. 
Ellen then headed backstage, the lights were dimmed and we all left the studio, not walking, but dancing.
